subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Parralel Systems
msgSnippet: ... The Latin alphabet isn t going away. We still sometimes use Roman numerals even though Arabic numerals are more common. I see no reason to stop using the
messageBody:
tim rice skribis:
>

> Over the thousands of years of its existence the
> Latin alphabet has aquired several parralel systems
> of communication closely assocciated to it. Some
> of the letters in sign language are exact copies of
> their written forms. Braille is designed for the current
> 26 letter alphabet and maritime flags are the same.
> Perhaps one of the underlying reasons several
> reform systems (including the Read alphabet for
> now) have not been accepted. Also, with a new order
> for the alphabet, and different names for the letters,
> what should the musical notes, when referred to as
> C, D, E, F, ect... be called?


The Latin alphabet isn't going away. We still sometimes
use Roman numerals even though Arabic numerals are
more common. I see no reason to stop using the Latin
letters for musical notes as well as the chemical elements.
Look at a Japanese chemistry book. You'll see Latin
chemical formulae mixed in with the kanji and kana of
the text.

A bigger question is what to do about acronyms. Many
are spoken as the names of their letters such as FBI,
CIA, and SEC. How would you pronounce these when
using an acronym in QS?

--Ph. D.
